Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 02:05PM joaniji wrote: Dear Anne, While I can't really offer advice on the removal of your tumor following your stage 4 diagnosis (although I think that I would want my tumor out too!), I can offer my input on the lung nodules.  Six months ago when I learned the cancer had returned, I had multiple bony lesions and multiple tiny lung nodules.  While my onc. was hesitant to say that the lung nodes were definitely cancer, hormonal treatment (Aromasin, Lupron and Zometa) seemed to do the job and recent scans showed the nodes were no longer there. This seems to indicate that the nodules were in fact cancerous. While it is scary to have had cancer spread to the lungs, perhaps my case can provide you with some reassurance that small lung nodules can be effectively treated!!  I am so sorry that you are experiencing this - I can completely relate to just wanting to survive for as long as possible (I have kids too).  I wish you all the best in making your decision.  Please have the strength to do what makes you more comfortable and secure.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2010 06:45AM joaniji wrote: Hi Pobster23, I am so sorry to hear that your mother is struggling with this miserable disease.  Watching her suffer must be so difficult for you; your care and concern for your mother are lovely and bound to help her fight this battle.  I guess that I would strongly encourage you to check with your mother's doc. about the use of a drug like Zometa (a bisphosphinate).  It seems pretty standard here on the board to hear about women with bone mets receiving infusions of bone building and cancer fighting medication.  I have had bone mets for 18 months and really feel like Zometa has helped prevent fractures, heal bone and fight the cancer.  Your mom's doc. referred to people not feeling well on these drugs - it does seem that most women have some flu like symptoms that last 48 hours of so.  The symptoms usually go away after the first few treatments. Bone mets are painful and can be disabling but they can be treated and the pain can be alleviated.  Please extend to you mom (and to yourself) our support and encouragement.  The board is visited by lovely, intelligent, compassionate and supportive women who don't hesitate to respond to questions rapidly and with deep respect.  Please post again if you like.  Wishing you and your mother the best, Joani

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 02:22PM joaniji wrote: Hi Katherine, I somewhat reluctantly applied for SSDI (as you know, here in Chicago) last summer and within 6 weeks I received my first payment.  That payment was an one-time lump sum payment covering the year that I had mets but was not on SSDI.  After this payment, I started receiving monthly stipends.  I have not discussed this with my onco. - all I did was bring copies of all the scans and blood work that I have had done, to the local SSDI office.  I had filled out the paperwork on line and even though I had left much of the paper work blank, the local office took care of it quickly, respectfully and thoroughly.  I completely understand being ambivalent about the whole thing - I receive my check and am thankful for it but remain ambivalent.  I don't know that this is the way to go for you, that decision can only be made by you.  Because I know you personally I can say that I would be amazed if you didn't find a job (if that is what you want).  You are so intelligent, write so well and are tech. savvy...a company would be blessed to have you.  Best to you, Joani

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 09:35AM joaniji wrote: Hi,  It is wonderful to hear that your cancer has responded positively to the chemo - this is great.  When I was diagnosed with mets three years ago a small biopsy from my bone was done and it determined that I was ER+, just like I had been when I had stage 2 cancer in 2004.  When the cancer spread to my liver in Sept. a liver biopsy was done and I was rediagnosed as TN.  This meant a treatment change to Xeloda and to my delight, the liver tumors are gone.  I do think that it is critical to get a biopsy (if it can be done) when your cancer spreads.  In reality though, the chemo drugs should be doing the job of the hormonals, in fighting cancer.  If the chemo is working then it makes sense to stay the course.  If your liver tumors return then I would recommend asking for a biopsy.  The other thing to consider is having an oopherectomy (ovaires out).  For me, this procedure was relatively simple and it helped give me peace of mind. I wish you the best.  Take good care, Joani

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 12:34PM joaniji wrote: Hi Jean, I know that any surgery is scary but as far as this one goes, my opinion is that it is a relatively uncomplicated surgery with a pretty straight forward recovery.  Are you having any reconstruction done at the same time?  I had reconstruction done at the time and although the surgery was made longer by this, I woke up with two breasts.  I would imagine that waking up with only one breast might be emotional for some, if this is the case for you, I wish you comfort and peace.  The actual surgery is under two hours and I think that you are able to go home after one day.  Usually women have a few drains that remain for a while.  This took some getting used to.  As far as pain, in my case, the pain was minimal.  It was a bit uncomfortable for a while, in particular when sleeping.  I found that lots of pillows, good food and pain killers if needed did the trick.  I truly hope that your recovery goes smoothly and that you get strength from knowing that you are removing some of the cancer.  Peace, Joani

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 09:17PM joaniji wrote: Hi, I am so sorry that you are having sleep issues and that your nurse doesn't seem to be empathic to this issue.  I have mbc and am a psychologist.  In all my years of practice -- and in my own experience-- I have found that the best long-term sleep aid is a medication called Trazadone.  This med is a very old anti-depressant and when taken at a sub-clinical dose (25 to 50mg) nightly, works wonders for most people.  Please don't hesitate to push your onc. to let you try something other than Ativan for sleep.  Ativan works for many people but it is primarily a fast acting anti-anxiety med that often doesn't allow for a full night sleep.  Hang in there.  Best to you, Joani

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 06:46PM joaniji wrote: Dear Patti,  My empathy and support goes out to you!!  I think that one of the challenges of dealing with this disease is that it contributes to emotions that are sometimes not readily understood, logical or predictable.  Although your mind is trying to use logic to understand your present funk, it is your heart and body doing the thinking here.  I truly believe that anniversary dates can trigger intense reactions that even great brains can't get a hold of.  Imagine your feelings as a bruise that isn't healing.  It hurts when suddenly hit.  Well, you are being banged again now and the mammogram is doing it!  I know from my experience, that my emotions and thoughts went wacko around the anniversary of my cancer mets diagnosis.  It was like the flood gates opened ... I was flooded by thoughts of my own demise, anger at my hubby for not making my life "perfect", worry about my kids, fury at my self for not being more "successful"... I can tell you though that these feelings did settle down - once the date passed and the scans were done, it was back to clear (well clearer!) thinking.  I hope that your blue mood is transitional but if it sticks around too long, please seek assistance (meds, food, pole dancing, primal scream therapy...I am trying to be funny here but I do appreciate the seriousness of the situation). Warm hugs are being sent your way.  Take good care.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 12:18PM - edited Jun 11, 2009 12:19PM by joaniji Hi Liz, I am sorry that you are in the unenviable position of needing to let your dear daughter know of your change in treatment.  As a parent of two (11 &13), I can completely relate.  While I am no means an expert in what you should say to your daughter, I can share some things that I found helpful to do with my kids.  I think being open and direct is key - she is no doubt smart and perceptive and will know something is going on even if you don't tell her.  Perhaps setting up a time on a weekly basis where you can update her on your health and answer any questions that she may have, would be helpful.  She may have worries about what will happen to her if you are sick or worse - letting her know of the people in her life that care about her might reduce her fears.  I found that it helped my boys to look at this disease as a management issue similar in some ways to diabetes.  I also gave them each a journal to use if they wanted to write about their feelings instead of sharing them with me. Perhaps the blessing of your daughter's age is that kids are usually pretty preoccupied with themselves (social stuff...)  I try to encourage my kids to keep on doing everything that they are doing even if it is being impossible adolescents!  It is truly heartbreaking to have to have this disease and to watch the pain it can cause our loved ones.  I am so sorry you have to deal with this.  My thoughts and best wishes are with you.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 05:37PM joaniji wrote: Dear Crazydaughter (no way are you crazy!!), I am so sorry for the turmoil and pain that your family is experiencing.  A diagnosis of mets. is crazy making - please give yourself the compassion you need to cope with this news. It sounds as if your mother is attempting to cope with her emotions by shutting down and withdrawing.  Please allow her and yourself time to adjust to this horrendous news.  If you can offer her your unconditional support while gently encouraging her to continue living life, this would be wonderful. With time, both of you will realize that while mets are definitely undesirable they do not usually mean an immediate death sentence.  Bone mets can be treated and controlled for a long period of time.  It has been one year since I was diagnosed with bone mets and there is no indication that the cancer is spreading.  This can happen for your mother as well.  Sometimes it takes several months before the Zometa and hormonal meds kick in.  If your mother is uncomfortable, then the best thing you can do for her is to advocate for her.  It doesn't seem right that she is suffering so much.  Please explore getting a second opinion, switching hormonal meds, adding pain killers and perhaps even therapy and medication. You sound like a loving and dedicated daughter, your mother is fortunate to have you.  Perhaps you can read your mother some of the responses to your post.  She must know that she is not alone and that there is hope.   I am wishing you both much peace and comfort.

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 08:27PM joaniji wrote: Please don't be afraid - while no one wants to have surgery, in my experience, a mastectomy is manageable.  After I was initially diagnosed with stage 2 bc I had a mastectomy and a tram flap reconstruction all at the same time.  While the surgery was long (5 hours) and I had to stay in the hospital for 4 days, I recovered pretty quickly.  I liked that I had the reconstruction at the same time; when I woke up I still had two breasts (one made out of excess abdominal skin).  The drains remained for about a week.  If you have a mastectomy only then the drains seem to come out within days.  I wish you the best as you go through this.  Take care of yourself, Joani

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 02:54AM joaniji wrote: Dear Heidi, I read your post with a heavy heart.  I know that this is a really awful time for you and that there is very little I can do to alleviate your pain.  I do know however, that you have an army of breast sisters behind you who are sending you much energy, compassion and support.  Please continue to use us all as your personal army!  You are faced with many tough decisions and difficult treatment options.  As a mother, I can relate to the wish to plan out the kids lives and to provide a protection plan that will guide them through the challenges of life.  When things feel so out of control, I know that the need to find a way to restore the balance of control is high.  Perhaps now though, the emphasis needs to be on taking care of you while keeping connected to your little ones in small ways.  It is the phone call you make to them from the hospital, the care package that you can have hubby deliver to them, the personal note that you can write from the hosp -- that will be treasured by your babes.  When you have energy, record your instructions, words of wisdom and sweet memories.   A dictation service can transcribe your recordings at a later date.  Right now, you need to focus on you for this will help the ones you love.  When you feel well enough staying connected to your kids in some of the ways familiar to them will likely help you both.  I think that the urge to micro manage this dreadful situation is so understandable but the bottom line is that no matter how much we do, our loved ones will deal with our illness in their own ways.  So, I think that it may be best to do what YOU need to feel as though you are retaining your beloved role as mother while you fight this miserable battle.  Just try not to expect yourself to do Everything!!  You are a fighter and a woman of strength.  Please feel the cyber hug I am sending you.  Be well girlfriend.  Love, Joani

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 07:56PM joaniji wrote: Hannah, this must be a frightening time for you and your mother, my best wishes go out to you both.  It sounds as if this is your mother's first progression since starting treatment for hormone positive mbc.  It is my understanding that hormonally driven cancers are first dealt with by using a variety of hormonal medication.  I take Aromasin but my onc is likely going to change me to Faslodex when progression in the bones is confirmed.  I think that chemo is used if the cancer spreads to the soft tissue or if widespread bone mets. occur.  Treatment should be specific to your mother though.  It sounds like she is in good hands at MDanderson.  Please don't assume that she is headed for a wheelchair.  As you will see on this forum, many many women live quite well with numerous bone mets.  Although I have mets to both hips, my spine, ribcage and chest, I continue to exercise and do most everything I have always done. Pain medication and sometimes radiation can work wonders by controlling the pain that bone mets can cause.  I wish you and your mother the best.  Please keep us posted. Joani

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 09:02AM joaniji wrote: Hi Jen, I am a psychotherapist and the mother of a 13 yr. old who is on anti-depressant medication.  I think that medication can be useful if its' use is carefully monitored and supplimented by non-medical therapy (talk, art, music...).  It was very difficult for me to agree to put my son on medication and I continue to be concerned however, it was the right decision.  Medication can be very helpful, especially in a situation in which a child's emotional suffering is threatening to disrupt the activities and experiences that the child loves.  Panic attacks can be debilitating and if left untreated, cause sufferers to experience anticipatory anxiety.  While cognitive-behavioral therapy has been proven effective for anxiety, such treatment is sometimes just not enough.  Anti-depressants do carry some risk but when carefully monitored they can help kids settle down enough to be able to learn more effective coping strategies.  Sometimes, an anti-anxiety medication used on an as needed basis is enough to let kids experience success in dealing with difficulties.  It is such a tough decision but you know your child the best and I am sure that you will make the best decision that you can make.  Medication has helped my son continue to enjoy all that he loves and when he is ready, we will slowly take him off.  The best to you and yours, Joani

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 09:08PM joaniji wrote: Congrats on being stable - that is great news!  I am not a doc. but my thought is that since the Abraxane worked well in getting your mets in control maybe the doc. wants to try a treatment that might be just as effective but a bit less toxic.  Faslodex is a newer hormonal treatment - it is usually given by injection in your butt.  The shots hurt a bit but since you only get them once a month, it is pretty tolerable.  In my case the side effects were minimal beyond the ache from the shot.  Sometimes Faslodex is used if you have already tried other hormonal meds and they stopped working.  Have you been on hormonals?  are you pre-menopausal?  The most in important thing is for you to be comfortable with the proposed treatment plan so, ask questions!!  Best of luck, Joani

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 02:18AM joaniji wrote: Perhaps I am feeling protectively toward you -- I would say GET A SECOND OPINION if you can, you don't sound as though you feel secure in the care your onc.  is providing.  I was diagnosed with bone mets after having a bone scan, pet scan, blood work and a bone biopsy.  My onc. also said that it was too hard to biopsy a hip so I had a small spot on my manubrium (chest) done. Although it was hard for the radiologist to get a big enough sample, the process was very comfortable and recovery swift.  I also had an x-ray of my hips, but this did not show the mets that were clearly evident on the Pet.  Be persistent, you deserve good care.  Wishing you all the best.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 07:29PM joaniji wrote: Hang in there...there is hope!  I am also 47 and while I was initially diagnosed with stage 4 hormone positive mbc, in September the cancer spread to my liver and a new biopsy determined that I am now TN.  I know that the literature points to a bleak future for people with TN but please remember that statistics are not accurate reflections of what will happen for YOU.  I can tell you that the chemo that I am on (Xeloda) has done wonders for me.  I am not in pain anymore from my bone mets and my liver mets are too small to show up on scans.  TN does respond well to chemo -- I know that it is a major bummer to be on chemo and I truly have a lot of empathy for you.  It is a scary diagnosis and it is okay to be upset, furious, devastated...whatever.  Please know that you can come here for support and guidance.  I don't think that there is an emotion or side effect that someone here hasn't experienced before!  I am so sorry that this has happened to you.  Feel free to PM me if you like.  Take good care, Joani PS.  Results from scans are often confusing.  Sometimes things show up on one scan but not another.  Once you and your docs. get a full sense of what is going on, then you may choose to repeat one type of scan every three months or so, to monitor your cancer.  I stick mostly to PET scans because this seems to be the most reliable scan for me - you will see what is best for you.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 11:30AM joaniji wrote: Becky, First, I am sorry for your situation - it never feels good to sense that others are acting in purely self-serving ways.  I have only one point to add to the astute comments of the women before me.  I don't want to sound presumptuous but I think that you may be confusing the issues a bit.  I sense that you wish (totally understandable) that your husband be treated with the same respect and consideration that you may wish (again understandable) that others treat you given your cancer.  While I would hope that people would be sensitive to you and your husband, your husband's role in the engineering department and the expectations placed on him are likely going to be different than the demands placed on you (per the cancer).  If your husband has concerns about the situation and wishes for a different class load then he needs to act accordingly.  But to hope that he be treated compassionately because of you, may be unrealistic.  I wish this weren't true but I am afraid it is.  Support him all that you can but it is probably his issue to fight.  Perhaps you can help him by helping him to articulate his feelings and to come up with a reasonable way to broach this issue with the dept. head.  You have enough fighting to do!! I hope that this makes sense.  I wish you and your husband the best.  Good luck, Joani

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 02:01PM joaniji wrote: It is absolutely understandable that you are feeling so miserable but it is absolutely NOT what you need to be experiencing.  When emotions leave you feeling hopeless, helpless, lethargic and discouraged for over two weeks, it usually means something biochemical is going on.  This in no way means that you are not competent or not coping well , it just means that this crappy disease is messing you up!!  Meds can definitely help, it may take some experimenting to find the right one and make sure you check how the meds interact with the cancer meds. you are on.  Remember that all the treatments that we have to endure can also wreck havoc with emotions.  I know that I was a complete basket case when I took Tamoxifen and again when I took Lupron.  I used lexepro for a while and have a prescription for Ativan to use when needed.  Please hang in there and try not to be so hard on yourself.  We are all behind you.  I hope that you feel better soon. Joani

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2013 06:19PM joaniji wrote: Sorry to say, but this does happen.  It happened to me!  I was diagnosed with stage 2 in 2004 and was Er+, in 2008 I was diagnosed with mets to the bone and a biopsy confirmed that I was still ER+.  Two and a half years later, I developed liver mets and a biopsy determined that I was TN.  It was a painful shock but I am still doing quite well, two years later.  There are many treatment options out there for TN.  Chemo can be very effective.  I am wishing the best for you and your wife.  I hope that your wife will tolerate her treatment well and that you can continue to enjoy your time!

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 03:22PM joaniji wrote: So sorry to hear that your recent scans showed that the ugly beast was invading you again!!  I know that cancer any where is rotten but I am glad to hear that it is not in your vital organs.  I had a bone biopsy in January and from this experience I understand that the sternum is generally the best place to get a biopsy.  The radiologist who did the biopsy said that bone biopsies can be difficult and sometimes necessitate breaking the bone.  Yuck!!  In my case, it took about six tries (all done while I was semi-under) but a small biopsy was done (without breaking the bone) that confirmed the cancer.  The treatment that I am on involves Zometa (a bone strengthening med.) and an hormonal med.  I hope that your biopsy is done quickly and easily - make sure they put you in twilight zone!!  I am thinking of you with warm and optimistic thoughts.  Take good care.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 04:27PM joaniji wrote: Dear Anne, Welcome to this forum and to a group of women who will happily offer you the support and encouragement that you need.  It is so understandable that you are worried, frightened and acutely aware of every sensation that your body feels.  I do think that with time, you will start to be able to distinguish between new pain and the pain that comes as your body begins to heal.  I was diagnosed with bone mets a year ago and have been on a treatment plan of Zometa and Aromasin.  I was initially on Lupron but found that med to be miserable! I had a lot of aches and hot flashes on Lupron so, over the summer I had my ovaries out.  This was a relatively easy procedure and has enabled me to stop lupron and begin Aromasin.  You may want to ask your doc. if the Lupron could be contributing to your pain.  As I have two broken ribs myself, I can relate to the pain such a break causes.  With a bit more time, the Zometa should start to help - it took about 6 months before I started to feel better.  I am not sure of the significance of the CEA but the CA 26-27 can be useful if the marker initially reflected the cancer.  28 is a good number though, wonderful!   I am so sorry that you have to find yourself in this situation, please know that there are many women here to listen to and support you along this journey.  Take good care, Joani

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 10:08AM - edited May 4, 2009 10:09AM by joaniji When my bone mets (to the ribs, vertebrae, sternum, and hip) were found on a PET scan I was sent to an interventional radiologist to biopsy a site to make sure the cancer was the same as the original bc.  The doc. ended up getting a sample from my sternum but he did say that it was difficult to do this because a biopsy from the bones often result in the bone breaking.  This definitely does not sound pleasant!  Maybe your doctor is concerned about the damage to the bone if a biopsy is done?  I feel for you - while I didn't want my bone to break I really did want to make sure that it was the cancer showing up and not something else.  I hope that you get some answers that feel sufficient for you.  Question the doctor!!  I am just learning to do this and it is hard but information can ease the anxiety.  Best to all.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 05:21PM joaniji wrote: I had to have a tooth extracted and because it was causing sooo much discomfort, I made the decision to have it pulled even though I was on Zometa.  I didn't have any trouble.  I do think that the optimal way to handle this is to be off the bone med for a couple of months before you have your dental procedure.  I know from my own experience that this is not always possible so, if it is not possible for you to wait rest assured that the risk of jaw problems is very low.  My dentist said that extractions were not as likely to cause jaw problems as an untreated infection or a more invasive root canal.  Best wishes!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 10:15AM joaniji wrote: Vivo,  I think that the stress and worry that you are feeling really are emotions that we all can relate to .  I am so sorry that you are feeling these feelings so sharply right now.  When I feel scared about a new symptom I have found it helpful to remind myself that the new symptom is not likely to kill me right NOW.  I know that this sounds odd, but reminding myself that cancer often grows slowly helps me to feel less overwhelmed and to believe that there is time - time to live and to fight.  Whatever the symptom is, it is likely that you will have time to get a plan in place and to FIGHT the cancer.  There are many treatments out there, please have faith that you will find something.  In the meantime, I think that RobinWendy's advice to compartmentalize is great.  It is so hard to do but imagine that cancer and then slam your mental door on it, and go tend to yourself.  Treat yourself compasssionately Vivo and come here for support.  We all care so much.  Joani

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 03:12PM joaniji wrote: I have learned from my own experience that understanding the pain behind bone mets is nearly impossible!! I too have mets to my sternum and have heard many explanations as to why the mets seem to act up at times.  It is true that when a new treatment starts, tumors often flare and cause pain that lessens as your body adjusts to the new protocol.  I have also heard that bone mets can hurt when they are dying (I especially like this explanation!).  Bone met pain can also be affected by the weather or by injury to the muscles that surround the met.  I guess that the most important thing is to treat yourself with compassion and bug your doctor to give you an explanation that you feel is sufficient.  I don't take pain meds much either but I really don't think that taking them means that you won't be aware of your cancer.  Pain meds might provide you some relief so that you can continue to do the things you love.  Your comfort is important.  I am thinking of you and wishing you the best.  Be well, Joani

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 11:26AM joaniji wrote: My understanding of why some docs order bone biopsies and others don't is that some times it is possible to do a bone biopsy without major destruction to the bone but sometimes to do a biopsy would involve breaking the bone and this is not good!  My onc. said that it was a good idea to do a biopsy if possible though because the biopsy would help determine the hormone status of the tumor.  My bone mets were diagnosed four years after my initial diagnosis with stage 2 bc so the biopsy was necessary to determine if the cancer was the same as the first one.  Hope this helps.  Best to all, joani

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2010 03:48PM joaniji wrote: If you do decide to start Zometa, there are some precautions you can take each time your visit your dentist.  I have a prescription for an antibiotic to take just before and after dental procedures (including cleanings).  As far as more significant dental work, I was told that the risk for future jaw problems is generally low so, it is okay to go ahead and do the dental work.  If you have the opportunity to get the work done, perhaps at a dental clinic with a sliding scale, it would be beneficial to get it done before starting Zometa.  I am not aware of other drugs that don't have the same potential risk.  Zometa has worked wonderfully for me and I hope that it will help you.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2010 08:03PM joaniji wrote: Frankie, I am sorry to hear that this is happening to you now.  I have had bone mets for the past 15 months and I have never heard my multiple lesions referred to by their size.  I do know that if you have a PET scan, the lesions are assigned a value - the lower the value the better.  In order to confirm bone mets, it is common to have a biopsy.  This can be hard to do if the bone is not easily accessed.  My biopsy was of the sternum - the radiologist said that this was the easiest place to reach.  I do think that if you don't have a biopsy, then a follow up bone scan would be helpful.  It is often hard to advocate for yourself in such an emotional time - is there someone who could push for a scan on your behalf? It is common to have scans (bone) every three months.  I hope that your next scan reveals that the lesion is due to an old injury!!  Best wishes to you for more comfort.  Enjova - welcome to this club - while no one wants to be here it seems that we make a good community.  Glad to hear that you are not in any discomfort - I hope that this continues for you. Are you also having Zometa? This is a drug given by infusion that helps fight the cancer in your bones as well as heal the existing lesions.  The best to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 01:04PM joaniji wrote: Dear Linda, Please don't be so hard on yourself.  I do think that whatever we are engaged in that is not good for us (relationships, eating patterns, work...) is part of our attempt to survive.  Sometimes, even bad relationships are serving needs that we have.  You are incredibly strong to now decide that you don't need this man in your life - I am sure that, although he is a bum, there are things that he has provided you that have felt good to you.  I guess the first part of getting out of a rotten situation is figuring out what needs were filled while in the lousy relationship.  Once you know what you got, then you can figure out new ways to get those needs met.  I hope that I am not sounding preachy - I am just trying to share some thoughts that I have.  It is so darn scary having this disease that it is soooo understandable that perhaps most of us at some point, stick with what we know even if it isn't the best.  Trying to tackle change when things can seem so out of control, can be overwhelming.  I wish you all the strength possible to make the changes that will, I hope, give you peace of mind and contentment.  The best wishes to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 08:00PM joaniji wrote: Hi Janis, been there and done that! My oldest (15) won't let me forget that in a fit of anxiety and frustration I called him a f---ing brat.  The problem is that because he is a teenager, he won't let me forget that I screwed up and did this ONCE.  The blessing of your sons youth is that they are less likely to hold on to this one episode and to use it to antagonize you!  Honestly, don't let this incident become evidence of your parenting.  I think that it is okay and absolutely understandable to lose it every once in a while - it lets others know that you are vulnerable too.  A few cosmos are definitely in order.  I wish you all the best as you go through your scans - the anticipatory anxiety has a life of its' own and can be so hard to get a handle on despite your best efforts.  It will pass.  Best of luck also with your foot - are you in pain.  I hope not.  Warmth and compassion, Joani

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 06:46PM joaniji wrote: Hi F&F's Mom, (had to shorten your name - hope you don't mind!). Like you I have multiple bones mets (entire chest area, vertebrae and hips) - I exercise regularly on the the elliptical machine.  This machine is low impact and can be adjusted for difficulty.  I used to run but I can't really do that any more.  I find that any exercise that involves standing for a long period of time is difficult.  The suggestion to try swimming is a wonderful one.  If I had a pool nearby, that is definitely something I would do.  I know that the risk of fracture is higher for us bone metsers so I do try to avoid any risky activities.  Basically I think the goal is to keep moving but to be careful not to push too hard.  I hope that you find an activity that you are comfortable doing because for me, activity helps remind me that I am living and surviving!  Best, Joani
